page.title: 04Mining
page.content: Before nationalisation, in 1946, all the mines were privately owned. A Mr. Charlesworth owned quite a few of the pits in this area, most of which were named after his daughters. Now_a_days open cast mining is more prevalent in Woodlesford and Oulton, than underground mining. Open cast changes the face of the landscape by re_routing rivers and literally moving mountains; but when the coal runs out, re_landscapes immediately. Whereas underground mining leaves scars which take many years to disappear, e.g. slag heaps and lift shafts still evident after 20 years of closure. Mining creates a "transient" community. As one pit closes the workers are sent to others. Often this means a move for the entire family, as happened with the recent closure of Rothwell "Fanny" pit.
